Tour of the most affected areas
According to information from Yahoo! News, King Felipe VI and Queen Letizia culminated this Friday a three-day tour of the communities most affected by the forest fires. After visiting Castilla y León and Galicia, they traveled to Extremadura, where they toured the towns of Rebollar, Cabezabellosa and Hervás, in the province of Cáceres.


In Rebollar, with barely 200 inhabitants, Felipe VI spoke with neighbors affected by the Jarilla fire, which forced the evacuation of the village. The monarch warned that thousands of Extremadurians "have lost their lives" and sought to convey "a message of support, affection and affection" to the victims.
Acknowledgment to brigades and emergency forces
Visit of the King and Queen to Cabezabellosa, in the region of Trasierra-Tierras de Granadilla, which was the first municipality evacuated together with Jarilla and Villar de Plasencia because of the forest fire. There they have greeted the neighbors and have conveyed their affection and support.... pic.twitter.com/yXfBJLITod
- Casa de S.M. el Rey (@CasaReal) August 29, 2025
In Cabezabellosa, one of the first municipalities evacuated, the King and Queen met with representatives of the bodies involved in the extinction: UME, Army, Civil Guard, Civil Protection, Red Cross Extremadura and the BRIF Pinofranqueado Miteco.
The head coordinator of the BRIF thanked the monarchs for the gesture of recognizing "the work done by all the operatives". A member of the UME highlighted the "very high demand" of the combat against the flames and recalled that they were always "in the front line as always".
Reflection and rural repopulation
In Hervás, Queen Letizia showed "sadness" and "gratitude" for the contact with the affected families. She insisted on the importance of "fixing population in the rural environment" to combat depopulation and strengthen the protection of inland areas.
King Felipe VI called for a "reflective, serene and humble" balance on how to improve the regulatory frameworks for fire prevention and extinction, warning that "it is always said that plans are useful until reality overflows them". He stressed that, despite the magnitude of the tragedy, "the vast majority of human life has been preserved".
Fires at historic levels
The context of the royal visit is a season marked by historic fires. According to the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), so far in 2025, 402,903 hectares have been burned in Spain, the third largest record since data has been available, behind only 1985 and 1994.
Five of the ten largest fires recorded in the country occurred this August in the province of Ourense, one of the hardest hit.
Emergency shared with Portugal
The crisis also affects Portugal, where 261,863 hectares have burned, the highest figure since 2017, when 114 people died and more than 563,000 hectares were burned.
Both countries are facing the most devastating wildfire summer in decades, posing a challenge for emergency management and international cooperation.
Unprecedented heat wave
The State Meteorological Agency (AEMET) confirmed that the August heat wave, with temperatures of up to 45 ºC for 16 days, was "the most intense since records have been kept".
The Carlos III Health Institute attributed more than 1,100 deaths to this episode, almost triple those recorded in July 2022 during the previous record. The extreme heat also favored the spread of fires across the Iberian Peninsula, which have left at least eight dead between Spain and Portugal.

Young innovators showcased technological solutionsfor environmental protection

The "Sustainable Development" hackathon co-organized by Azercell
and Eventify took place at Oxbridge Academy on January 18, 2025.
The initiative aimed to unlock the innovative potential of the
young people, while fostering the development of environmentally
focused technologies, and advancing the startup ecosystem in
Azerbaijan.

The competition brought together 11 teams of young participants
aged between 12 and 18 years old. Over six hours, the teams worked
on technological challenges addressing issues of environmental
protection. Guided by experienced mentors, the young innovators
developed prototypes of their concepts and presented their
solutions to a panel of judges.

The "Bono" team secured first place with a project, which
promotes environmental engagement through a point-based reward
system. The second place was awarded to the "Homeboys" team for
their sustainable city initiative, while the "JoshuaTech" team
earned third place for their proposal to leverage drones for forest
fire prevention.

The winning teams were rewarded with prizes and special gifts
from Azercell.

urn:contentItem:6GS8-C943-S3XJ-921K-00000-00Spain's 2025 summer was hottest on record2025-09-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:14ZLexisNexisSpain's 2025 summer was hottest on record

Madrid, Sep. 17 (BNA): This summer was Spain's hottest since records began in 1961, as the country experienced more than a month of heatwaves caused by climate change that helped stoke its worst season of wildfires in three decades.

The summer of 2025 was 2.1 degrees Celsius warmer than the 1991-2020 average and surpassed the previous warmest summer recorded in 2022 by 0.1 degrees, state weather agency AEMET said.

Nine of the 10 hottest summers in Spain have occurred in the 21st century, with more heat to come, AEMET spokesperson Ruben del Campo said in an interview with Reuters.

"These summers of 2022 and 2025 are a trailer - or spoiler - for what could happen in the middle of the century," del Campo said. "One in every three days this summer we have been under a heatwave."

Del Campo said Spain would need to adapt to hotter summers while continuing to contribute to the global effort to curb climate change by reducing emissions of greenhouse gases.

Spain experienced three heatwaves spanning 36 days during the summer. A 16-day heatwave in August saw temperatures exceed 45C in the south of the country and was the most intense on record, according to AEMET.

Countries across the world are experiencing record-breaking heat in recent years as global warming accelerates. The summer of 2024 was the northern hemisphere's warmest while summer 2025 was Britain's hottest since records began in 1884.

Intense heat helped fan wildfires that burned through a record 1.03 million hectares (nearly 4,000 square miles) across the European Union, according to data by the EU's European Forest Fire Information System.

In the inland part of Spain's northwestern region of Galicia, which suffered some of the worst blazes, temperatures were 3C warmer than normal, AEMET said.

urn:contentItem:6GKD-SNK3-RSVS-81KC-00000-00Pakistan achieves 68pc target of planting trees under Green Pakistan Program2025-08-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:14ZLexisNexisPakistan achieves 68pc target of planting trees under Green Pakistan Program

Pakistan has successfully achieved 68 percent of its tree plantation target under the government's flagship initiative, the 'Upscaling Green Pakistan Program' which aims at combating climate change, enhancing forest cover and restoring degraded ecosystems across the country.

According to official documents available with Wealth Pakistan, the Ministry of Climate Change and Environmental Coordination, in collaboration with provincial governments, planted more than 2.22974 billion saplings between 2019 and December 2024, against the overall target of 3.29 billion saplings by 2028.

Sindh emerged as the top-performing province by planting 856.01 million saplings, achieving 85 percent of its set target. Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) followed with 713.25 million plantations, while Punjab contributed 364.79 million, achieving 77 percent of its goal. Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK) planted 177.05 million, and Gilgit-Baltistan (GB) accounted for 94.10 million plantations. In Balochistan, 24.55 million saplings were planted during the review period.

The program's annual progress breakdown includes 492.03 million saplings in 2019, 595.37 million in 2020, 766.50 million in 2021, 233.41 million in 2022, and 125.99 million in 2023.

A senior Ministry official told Wealth Pakistan that Pakistan loses nearly 11,000 hectares of forest land annually due to wildfires, climate change, and land conversion. To address this alarming trend, the government has coupled plantation drives with several structural and policy interventions.

An interprovincial coordination committee was constituted to curb illegal logging and regulate inter-provincial timber movement. The committee regularly highlights challenges faced by the forestry sector and issues recommendations for compliance.

In line with Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif's directives, the Ministry has also developed Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) on forest fire management in coordination with all provinces, AJK, and GB. Forest fire monitoring data is now systematically collected and reviewed at the national level. Additionally, an early warning system prototype has been installed in two valleys of KP and is currently in the testing phase.

The Federal Forestry Board has also been revived to address deforestation challenges and ensure alignment with the National Forest Policy 2017. Moreover, provinces have updated their forestry-related laws and policies, including the Punjab Forestry Policy 2019, Sindh Sustainable Forest Management (SFM) Policy 2023 (Amended), KP Forest Ordinance 2002, KP Protected Forest Management Rules 2005, Balochistan Forest Act 2022, GB Forest Act 2019, GB Forest Force Rules 2020, GB Wildlife Biodiversity Areas Act 2021 and AJK Forest Regulations (Amendment) Act 2017.

In addition to inland plantation, the country has recorded remarkable progress in mangrove restoration. Since the early 1990s, mangrove cover along Pakistan's coastal areas has increased by 300 percent, making Pakistan the only country in the region with an expanding mangrove forest cover.

urn:contentItem:6GKD-SN33-RRRD-638V-00000-00Pakistan achieves 68pc target of planting trees under Green Pakistan Programme2025-08-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:14ZLexisNexisPakistan achieves 68pc target of planting trees under Green Pakistan Programme

Pakistan has successfully achieved 68 percent of its tree plantation target under the government's flagship initiative, the 'Upscaling Green Pakistan Programme' which aims at combating climate change, enhancing forest cover and restoring degraded ecosystems across the country. According to official documents available with Wealth Pakistan, the Ministry of Climate Change and Environmental Coordination, in collaboration with provincial governments, planted more than 2.22974 billion saplings between 2019 and December 2024, against the overall target of 3.29 billion saplings by 2028. Sindh emerged as the top-performing province by planting 856.01 million saplings, achieving 85 percent of its set target. Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) followed with 713.25 million plantations, while Punjab contributed 364.79 million, achieving 77 percent of its goal. Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK) planted 177.05 million, and Gilgit-Baltistan (GB) accounted for 94.10 million plantations. In Balochistan, 24.55 million saplings were planted during the review period.

The programme's annual progress breakdown includes 492.03 million saplings in 2019, 595.37 million in 2020, 766.50 million in 2021, 233.41 million in 2022, and 125.99 million in 2023. A senior ministry official told Wealth Pakistan that Pakistan loses nearly 11,000 hectares of forest land annually due to wildfires, climate change, and land conversion. To address this alarming trend, the government has coupled plantation drives with several structural and policy interventions. An interprovincial coordination committee was constituted to curb illegal logging and regulate inter-provincial timber movement. The committee regularly highlights challenges faced by the forestry sector and issues recommendations for compliance. In line with Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif's directives, the ministry has also developed Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) on forest fire management in coordination with all provinces, AJK, and GB. Forest fire monitoring data is now systematically collected and reviewed at the national level. Additionally, an early warning system prototype has been installed in two valleys of KP and is currently in the testing phase. The Federal Forestry Board has also been revived to address deforestation challenges and ensure alignment with the National Forest Policy 2017. Moreover, provinces have updated their forestry-related laws and policies, including the Punjab Forestry Policy 2019, Sindh Sustainable Forest Management (SFM) Policy 2023 (Amended), KP Forest Ordinance 2002, KP Protected Forest Management Rules 2005, Balochistan Forest Act 2022, GB Forest Act 2019, GB Forest Force Rules 2020, GB Wildlife Biodiversity Areas Act 2021 and AJK Forest Regulations (Amendment) Act 2017.

In addition to inland plantation, the country has recorded remarkable progress in mangrove restoration. Since the early 1990s, mangrove cover along Pakistan's coastal areas has increased by 300 percent, making Pakistan the only country in the region with an expanding mangrove forest cover.

2025 SEP 29 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Math Daily News -- New research on mathematics is the subject of a new report. According to news reporting originating from the Universitas Tanjungpura by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "One of the models that is utilized in spatio-temporal analysis is known as the Generalized Space-Time Autoregressive (GSTAR). This model incorporates two dimensions, namely the geographical and temporal aspects of the situation."


The news editors obtained a quote from the research from Universitas Tanjungpura: "This approach assists in the identification of patterns and correlations between data by taking into account both spatial and temporal elements. From modeling the confidence level of forest fire hotspot cases in Kubu Raya and its surrounds using the GSTAR (1;1) model with three different combinations of grids and special weight matrices, the purpose of this study is to discover which combination of grids and spatial weight matrices is the most effective. The results of diagnostic tests and the degrees of MAPE accuracy are used to determine which model is the most suitable. The data was obtained from the FIRMS-NASA platform, ranging from January 2014 to August 2024. A grid with a dimension of 1.25 x 1.25 degrees and a rook contiguity weight matrix is a combination of grids and spatial weight matrices that meet the white noise assumption, according to the findings of the study. This conclusion is based on the diagnostic test."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "As a result, the combination of a grid with a size of 1.25 x 1.25 and a rook contiguity weight matrix is the best in this modeling. This combination has a MAPE of 11.797%, which indicates that this model has a good level of accuracy."
For more information on this research see: The GSTAR (1;1) Modelling with Three Combination of the Grid Sizes and Spatial Weight Matrix in Forest Fires Cases. JTAM (Jurnal Teori dan Aplikasi Matematika), 2025,9(1):134-146. The publisher for JTAM (Jurnal Teori dan Aplikasi Matematika) is Universitas Muhammadiyah Mataram.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.31764/jtam.v9i1.27543.

A forest fire continues active in Carballeda de Valdeorras (Orense), in the parish of Casaio, since Saturday afternoon and burns more than 500 hectares, according to provisional estimates of the Ministry of Rural Environment.


However, strong gusts of wind are hindering the work of extinguishing the fire, which started at 14.56 last day. Neighborhood sources point out that it started above the old wolfram mine of Valborraz. In addition, they indicate that, in the early morning, it was spreading and even "threatening" the village.
For the moment, three technicians, 18 agents, 22 brigades, 21 motor pumps, four shovels, three technical support units, six helicopters and four airplanes have been mobilized to extinguish the fire.
In addition, the Brigade of Reinforcement in Forest Fires (BRIF) based in Tabuyo del Monte (León) has moved to the site to join the means already sent by the Xunta.
This parish already suffered another fire in August, which devastated 5,300 hectares -according to the Xunta's figures- in the surroundings of the Trevinca mountains. However, on that occasion it was a fire originated in Porto, in the region of Sanabria (Zamora), which crossed the border with Ourense.
This time, it did not come from the border province, as sources from the Rural Environment Department have reported, but originated in the town of Ourense.

A1Experts see more dry weather on the horizon Weather Conditions persist as 'fire weather' season begins in ConnecticutStephen Underwood Hartford Courant

Photo Caption: The River Road bridge crosses the low waters of the Hammonasset River in Madison on Tuesday. Drought conditions are evident across Connecticut, especially in the southeastern part of the state. Aaron Flaum/Hartford Courant photos Photo Caption: Low water levels are visible in the Hammonassett River in Madison.

As Connecticut starts off October with mild temperatures and lots of sunshine, the state is facing abnormally dry conditions with the potential to turn into a moderate drought as the start of the fall wildfire season begins, forecasters said.

Amid a mild stretch this past week, Connecticut has seen temperatures mostly in the upper 70s and low 80s, with mostly sunny and humid conditions, according to AccuWeather meteorologists. Forecasters now say mild temperatures are expected to continue this month with a forecast of mostly dry weather.

According to the U.S. Drought Monitor, the entire state is listed as "abnormally dry" conditions. The southeast

part of the state along the shoreline in New London County is listed as being in moderate drought.

"If you end the summer on a dry note and start losing leaves in the fall, that is fuel for fire," Accuweather senior meteorologist Paul Pastelok said.

"The thing that we should be thankful for is that there hasn't been a lot of wind. So any wildfires we might have had already didn't have a chance to really kick up. We did have a few days of rain last week that actually reduced our level from a drought to just abnormally dry conditions. That rain really helped us out."

Pastelok said that dry conditions will continue for most of the week until next Wednesday, with more warmer conditions setting in. Much of the Northeast is experiencing dry or drought conditions. Northern New England, including parts of Maine and New Hampshire, are currently listed as extreme drought conditions, according to the U.S. Drought Monitor.

"Getting rain for a day and then drying out for five or six days afterwards is not good," Pastelok said. "That's going to be the patten through at least mid to late October. Because after the rain event next week, another big high pressure system builds right behind it. So it will most likely dry out again for several days afterwards."

So far this year, 29.62 inches of rainfall has been recorded in Connecticut, well below the 37.34 inch average for this time of year, according to RainDrop.com. September saw just 2.59 inches of accumulated rainfall, and August saw just 1.60 inches.

"The state is averaging about 60 to 65 percent of average rainfall, which is below average," Pastelok said.

"Without the tropics or anything coming out of the Gulf of Mexico, it doesn't change our weather pattern. If it doesn't get wet in Tennessee and down to the Mississippi Valley, then it stays mostly dry in the Northeast as well, because that's often where our air is coming from," he said. "So since it's been dry down there with no tropical moisture coming up and affecting our pattern, I think that's why we've had a below average year for rainfall."

As dry conditions persist, the risk of devastating wildfires increases. The dry weather stretch comes as the state still reels from a series of devastating wildfires last year that led to the death of a Wethersfield firefighter. The Hawthorne fire in Berlin, which consumed more than 100 acres at its peak, was one of the largest in the state in decades. Through September, there have been six brush fires reported in the state, according to the Wildland Fire Reporting System through the state's Department of Energy and Environmental Protection.

Connecticut has two forest fire seasons: spring fire season, normally mid-March to mid-May, and fall fire season, according to Accuweather.

Fall wildfire season varies by region but is generally considered the period from mid-September or October until the first snowfall, characterized by dry, windy conditions that increase fire risk. In Connecticut, it runs from October to the first snowfall, with dry, windy conditions and fallen leaves act as fuel for fires.

Over the next few weeks, dry and potentially windy weather conditions, combined with fallen leaves and increased sunlight reaching and warming the forest floor, can elevate the likelihood of wildfires, according to state officials.

Water use

Connecticut Water, which serves 60 towns in Connecticut has issued a notice to its customers that, "due to abnormally dry conditions and low rain forecast levels, Connecticut Water has issued conservation requests for customers in the following towns: Clinton, Madison, Guilford, Old Saybrook, Westbrook and Plymouth."

"Using water wisely will ensure available supply for public health and fire protection. This request is until further notice. We will continue to update customers on drought status," the company notice says.

The Metropolitan District, a non-profit municipal corporation, reports in its most recent data that it reservoir levels as of August 31 are at 94.7% of capacity. The MDC notes that its surface water supply system of reservoirs includes: 30.3 billion gallon Barkhamsted Reservoir and 9.5 billion gallon Nepaug Reservoir.

"Because of the large size of its reservoirs relative to the amount of water typically used, the MDC is better able to meet water use demands during drought conditions," according to the MDC.

The MDC supplies water to eight member towns, Bloomfield, East Hartford, Hartford, Newington, Rocky Hill, West Hartford, Wethersfield and Windsor, but also to portions of Farmington, Glastonbury, East Granby and South Windsor, which the agency's non-member towns.

While the South Central Regional Water Authority, which serves 15 towns in Greater New Haven, says "the level of water in reservoirs rises and falls throughout the year," it list its reservoirs at 72% of capacity.as of Sept. 15. The usual capacity at this time of year is 71 percent, according to the agency. Further, according to the RWA, it on average, supplies 42.3 million gallons of water a day to nearly 432,000 people.

Pastelok said that October and November tend to be more dry months due to persistent high-pressure systems that block moisture from the Gulf of Mexico and create dry, westerly wind flows, leading to less precipitation and increased drought conditions.

Connecticut experienced record wildfires last fall, with 605 fires burning more than 500 acres, destroying eight structures and disrupting communities across the state, a spokesperson with DEEP said. Last year, Gov. Ned Lamont declared a state of emergency, issued a statewide burn ban and activated the Northeast Forest Fire Protection Compact, bringing in support from other states and the National Guard. During the last wildlife season, eight firefighters were injured.

As wildfires continue to be a major risk, Lamont and Connecticut Insurance Department commissioner Andrew Mais announced the launch of a free online risk mapping tool that allows Connecticut homeowners and businesses to assess their property's risk from flooding, wildfires and other perils to better understand their insurance needs.

Provided through a public-partnership between CID and First Street, a global provider of physical climate risk data and analytics, the mapping tool gives residents access to property-level data through interactive maps and risk-rating reports. By entering an address, homeowners and businesses can immediately see their property's exposure to a range of climate-related risks such as flooding, wildfire, hurricane winds, extreme heat and air quality.

State officials say the majority of wildfires in Connecticut are caused by improper burning of debris, arson, campfires and discarded wood ashes and equipment.

urn:contentItem:6GKD-SNX3-RT20-J3XG-00000-00Pakistan achieves 68pc target of planting trees under Green Pakistan Program2025-08-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:14ZLexisNexisPakistan achieves 68pc target of planting trees under Green Pakistan Program

Pakistan has successfully achieved 68 percent of its tree plantation target under the government's flagship initiative, the 'Upscaling Green Pakistan Program' which aims at combating climate change, enhancing forest cover and restoring degraded ecosystems across the country.

According to official documents available with Wealth Pakistan, the Ministry of Climate Change and Environmental Coordination, in collaboration with provincial governments, planted more than 2.22974 billion saplings between 2019 and December 2024, against the overall target of 3.29 billion saplings by 2028.

Sindh emerged as the top-performing province by planting 856.01 million saplings, achieving 85 percent of its set target. Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) followed with 713.25 million plantations, while Punjab contributed 364.79 million, achieving 77 percent of its goal. Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK) planted 177.05 million, and Gilgit-Baltistan (GB) accounted for 94.10 million plantations. In Balochistan, 24.55 million saplings were planted during the review period.

The program's annual progress breakdown includes 492.03 million saplings in 2019, 595.37 million in 2020, 766.50 million in 2021, 233.41 million in 2022, and 125.99 million in 2023.

A senior Ministry official told Wealth Pakistan that Pakistan loses nearly 11,000 hectares of forest land annually due to wildfires, climate change, and land conversion. To address this alarming trend, the government has coupled plantation drives with several structural and policy interventions.

An interprovincial coordination committee was constituted to curb illegal logging and regulate inter-provincial timber movement. The committee regularly highlights challenges faced by the forestry sector and issues recommendations for compliance.

In line with Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif's directives, the Ministry has also developed Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) on forest fire management in coordination with all provinces, AJK, and GB. Forest fire monitoring data is now systematically collected and reviewed at the national level. Additionally, an early warning system prototype has been installed in two valleys of KP and is currently in the testing phase.

The Federal Forestry Board has also been revived to address deforestation challenges and ensure alignment with the National Forest Policy 2017. Moreover, provinces have updated their forestry-related laws and policies, including the Punjab Forestry Policy 2019, Sindh Sustainable Forest Management (SFM) Policy 2023 (Amended), KP Forest Ordinance 2002, KP Protected Forest Management Rules 2005, Balochistan Forest Act 2022, GB Forest Act 2019, GB Forest Force Rules 2020, GB Wildlife Biodiversity Areas Act 2021 and AJK Forest Regulations (Amendment) Act 2017.

In addition to inland plantation, the country has recorded remarkable progress in mangrove restoration. Since the early 1990s, mangrove cover along Pakistan's coastal areas has increased by 300 percent, making Pakistan the only country in the region with an expanding mangrove forest cover.

The most recent social conflict affecting the operation of Machu Picchu has its origin in the lack of order in the bidding process and transition of the operation of tourist buses on the Hiram Bingham route, which connects Machu Picchu Pueblo with the llaqta.

According to sector unions, the problem arises from the failure of the Provincial Municipality of Urubamba, which did not organize the public tender in time. As a consequence, locals staged protests and blockades, including the throwing of stones from the slopes, putting visitors, personnel and neighbors in the area at risk.
The situation led the railway companies to indefinitely suspend train services between Ollantaytambo and Machu Picchu, leaving hundreds of tourists stranded and directly affecting the main economic activity of the Cusco region.
The unions recalled that this episode reflects a structural crisis in the Sanctuary's management due to the dispersion of functions among institutions such as the Cusco's Decentralized Culture Office (Ministry of Culture), Sernanp (Ministry of Environment), Mincetur, Cusco's Regional Government, and the municipalities of Urubamba and Machu Picchu.
In view of this, they proposed that the Presidency of the Council of Ministers (PCM) assume a leadership role and adopt measures such as:

Declare Machu Picchu Picchu a National Critical Asset to protect its strategic infrastructure.

Install an inter-institutional technical table to reestablish order and guarantee legal security and free transit.

Transparency and formalization of the transportation service bidding process.

Create a National Autonomous Authority that concentrates and articulates the sanctuary's integral management.

urn:contentItem:6GS3-RCC3-RS97-73GX-00000-00Fire in Caylloma: set on fire to scare away a puma and razed 300 hectares2025-09-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:14ZLexisNexisFire in Caylloma: set on fire to scare away a puma and razed 300 hectares


The mayor of Tisco, Lino Maque Saico, reported that the forest fire that started on the afternoon of September 15 was probably caused by an attempt to scare off a puma. The official indicated that the fire devastated some 300 hectares of natural grasslands due to the strong wind blowing from the southwest to the northeast, which accelerated the spread of the flames in a rugged and rocky terrain.


According to the burgomaster, the fire was allegedly caused by a local family that lit a fire in the pastures to scare off a puma. "This animal had attacked four alpacas in their troop and, in order to scare it away, they set the fire. But at this time of year, fire is very agile, it quickly catches fire and begins to devour the whole area," he said.
The mayor explained that the work to contain the fire lasted until late at night with the support of residents, serenazgo and municipal personnel. "It was uncontrollable, the area is rugged and rocky. With the support of the population we managed to control it around 11 o'clock at night, but it restarted in the early hours of the morning and we had to fight it again", he said. Finally, he said that the fire was controlled during the early hours of Tuesday morning.
To reinforce the control work, the Regional Emergency Operations Center (COER) Arequipa sent 10 brigade members who had to reach the area on foot due to the lack of vehicular access. Likewise, an Army contingent moved in with water backpacks to suffocate the fires that were still active. According to the COER, no damage to life or health was reported, although vigilance is being maintained to prevent the flames from reactivating.

urn:contentItem:6GS4-4H43-RTDV-T0KH-00000-00Arequipa: Sernanp confirms fire in Cotahuasi after four days of uninterrupted care2025-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:14ZLexisNexisArequipa: Sernanp confirms fire in Cotahuasi after four days of uninterrupted care

Twelve forest fighters of Sernanp managed to extinguish the fire that devastated about 450 hectares of Puna.The National Service of Natural Areas Protected by the State (Sernanp), an agency attached to the Ministry of Environment, confirmed the total extinction of the forest fire that for four days threatened the sub -basin landscape reserve of Cotahuasi (RPSCC), in Arequipa.

At 8:00 a.m. From September 10, a team of 12 forest fighters of the RPSCC and the National Reserve of Salinas and Aguada Blanca culminated the liquidation work throughout the affected area. Two hours later, at 10:40 a.m., the Intendance Command ordered the demobilization of the staff, ending one of the most challenging emergencies of recent years in the Arequipa Puna.

The images recorded in the area show the dimension of the challenge: brigades moving on soils converted into ash, combatants armed with manual tools, water backpacks, forest blowers and smoke columns dissipating in the middle of a devastated mountain landscape.

The fire is completely extinguished and no longer represents a risk of reactivation. Now we will begin the impact evaluations and the reinforcement of prevention measures, said Juan Jose Bustinza, head of the RPSCC.

The fire, started on September 5 in the Pitahuasi -Huambo Allhuay sector, consumed around 450 hectares of grasslands and pajonal puna. There were no human victims or direct damage to health, thanks to the rapid and coordinated action of the Sernanp combatants, supported by residents of peasant communities, provincial municipality of the Union, National Police of Peru, Regional Government of Arequipa and local authorities.

With this action, Sernanp reaffirms its commitment to protect the protected natural areas of the country and strengthen, together with communities and authorities, prevention and response measures against forest fires.

urn:contentItem:6GYH-1V33-RSVV-54ST-00000-00Coulson Aviation Challenges Saskatchewan's $135M Q400 Deal2025-09-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:14ZLexisNexisAviation and Travel Business News - Airline Industry InsightsCoulson Aviation Challenges Saskatchewan's $135M Q400 Deal

Coulson Aircrane, part of Canada's Coulson Aviation, has filed a lawsuit in the Court of King's Bench to overturn Saskatchewan's CAD187 million (USD135.5 million) contract with Conair Group for four DHC-8-Q400(AT) firefighting aircraft. The company alleges the provincial government awarded "a very large contract for forest fire airplanes" without giving Coulson or other competitors a fair opportunity to bid, CBC News reported. <!-- /wp:paragraph --> <!-- wp:paragraph -->

In a statement to ch-aviation, Coulson Aviation said government procurement should be transparent, especially for large expenditures. While Coulson does not currently build Q400 Type 2 airtankers, it claims it could deliver the same specifications "for half the price." The company estimates a used Q400 costs around CAD5 million (USD3.6 million) and another CAD5 million to retrofit, compared to Conair's price of more than CAD46 million (USD33.3 million) per unit. <!-- /wp:paragraph --> <!-- wp:paragraph -->

Twelve forest fighters of Sernanp managed to extinguish the fire that devastated about 450 hectares of Puna.The National Service of Natural Areas Protected by the State (Sernanp), an agency attached to the Ministry of Environment, confirmed the total extinction of the forest fire that for four days threatened the sub -basin landscape reserve of Cotahuasi (RPSCC), in Arequipa.

At 8:00 a.m. From September 10, a team of 12 forest fighters of the RPSCC and the National Reserve of Salinas and Aguada Blanca culminated the liquidation work throughout the affected area. Two hours later, at 10:40 a.m., the Intendance Command ordered the demobilization of the staff, ending one of the most challenging emergencies of recent years in the Arequipa Puna.

The images recorded in the area show the dimension of the challenge: brigades moving on soils converted into ash, combatants armed with manual tools, water backpacks, forest blowers and smoke columns dissipating in the middle of a devastated mountain landscape.

The fire is completely extinguished and no longer represents a risk of reactivation. Now we will begin the impact evaluations and the reinforcement of prevention measures, said Juan Jose Bustinza, head of the RPSCC.

The fire, started on September 5 in the Pitahuasi -Huambo Allhuay sector, consumed around 450 hectares of grasslands and pajonal puna. There were no human victims or direct damage to health, thanks to the rapid and coordinated action of the Sernanp combatants, supported by residents of peasant communities, provincial municipality of the Union, National Police of Peru, Regional Government of Arequipa and local authorities.

With this action, Sernanp reaffirms its commitment to protect the protected natural areas of the country and strengthen, together with communities and authorities, prevention and response measures against forest fires.

urn:contentItem:6GKM-RH93-RSJJ-04K3-00000-00Mongolia pushes '1 Billion Trees' project to fight desertification, seeks Korea's support 2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:14ZLexisNexisMongolia pushes '1 Billion Trees' project to fight desertification, seeks Korea's support

ULAANBAATAR, Mongolia ? The most frequently mentioned keyword at the Korea-Mongolia Future Strategy Forum last week was Mongolia's "Planting 1 Billion Trees" project.

Tserendorj Uranchimeg, director general of Mongolia's Natural Resources Policy and Coordination Department at the Ministry of Environment and Climate Change, introduced the initiative during the forum, co-hosted by Herald Media Group and Anse Foundation, held at the Government Palace in Ulaanbaatar on Aug. 20.

"For Mongolians, the Earth is their mother," she said while presenting the project.

Launched in 2021 when Mongolian President Ukhnaa Khurelsukh announced the campaign at the UN General Assembly, the project aims to plant 1 billion trees nationwide by 2030 to combat desertification and mitigate the climate crisis by expanding forest cover.

"The first goal is to plant trees in urban areas to create a stable ecological environment, and the second is to plant trees in desert areas to reduce yellow dust," Uranchimeg explained.

"Among these are also fruit trees that can provide food. We are not just planting trees, but also working to protect them," she added. "The government is also fostering cooperation with the private sector and implementing policies to support businesses in planting trees or investing in local communities."

In June, the Korea Forest Service held a meeting in Bogant Soum, Selenge province, with Mongolia's Ministry of Environment and Climate Change, the Korea-Mongolia Greenbelt Project team and local authorities.

The meeting reviewed achievements and future cooperation plans for the third phase of their joint project, commemorating the completion of key infrastructure such as the Selenge nursery farm, an afforestation training center and a forest fire response system.

The Selenge nursery farm, spanning 150,000 hectares, is a major seedling production facility. Its seedlings will be used to restore forest fire damage and support Mongolia's "Planting 1 Billion Trees" campaign.

"It is important to establish an institutional framework so that NGOs and companies engaged in tree planting can benefit from the global carbon market. In this regard, we would like to ask the Korean side to consider the plan we are developing through this forum," said Bat-Erdene Bat-Ulzii, head of the Mongolia-Republic of Korea Parliamentary Friendship Group. Republic of Korea is South Korea's official name.

"Ultimately, we want to create a system where individuals, organizations and institutions that plant trees can receive economic benefits in the global market," he added.

Professor Jung Tae-yong of Yonsei University, who moderated the session, said, "Climate change is no longer an issue that any country can avoid. Mongolia must continue to face this challenge, and it is highly meaningful to explore solutions together through the forum."

"Addressing climate change alone is not enough. The greatest challenges of the 21st century are climate change and digital transformation. Solutions that combine digital and green approaches will be the most suitable for Mongolia," he added.

Cusco: tourism still does not recover pre-pandemic levels and affects regional developmentComexPeru warns that the lack of official promotion and social protests discourage the arrival of international visitors.

Cusco: senior citizen dies trapped in the middle of a forest fire

Luis Álvarez
Tourism, Cusco's main economic engine, has not yet managed to return to pre-pandemic levels. According to a report by ComexPeru, in 2024 the economic contribution of foreign tourists in visits to Machu Picchu reached S/ 175 million, lower than the S/ 185 million recorded in 2019, before the health crisis.


The study indicates that, between January and June of this year, the region received 2.2 million passengers by air, but only 700,319 of them reached the historic sanctuary. This difference reflects that many visitors use Cusco as a transit destination, without generating the expected impact on the local economy.
According to ComexPerú, the lack of tourism promotion campaigns by the Government, added to social protests, has discouraged the arrival of international visitors. As a result, the lodging and restaurant sector is lagging behind pre-pandemic figures by nearly 20%.
In terms of employment, tourism contributes significantly, although still insufficient. In 2024, the lodging and restaurant sector generated 64,321 jobs, which represents an increase compared to 2022; however, informality continues to predominate in the region, with more than 617,000 workers in this condition.
The business association warns that overcoming this stagnation requires a sustained promotion plan, improvements in infrastructure and social stability, in order to consolidate tourism as a true engine of development for the region.

The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change (MMA) published in the Federal Official Gazette, last Monday (1/9), the resolution that defines technical criteria for the implementation of prevention and preparation measures to forest fires in rural real estate, established in.

Access the resolution

Approved in the beginning of August, the measure seeks to reduce irregular or illegal ignitions that may cause forest fires, as well as encouraging planning, implementation of prevention actions and joining joint actions to reduce the occurrence and impacts caused by forest fires.

Resolution prohibits the use of fire in pasture, agricultural areas or forest management areas without prior and formal authorization of the responsible environmental agency. It also determines as a preventive measure the use of monitoring, communication and alert systems and devices for the activation of private local brigades or military fire brigade.

All rural properties, with the exception of family farmers, should elaborate and implement the measures of the National Fire Management Policy (PMIF) or the Operative Plan for Forest Fire Prevention and Combat.

The standard establishes mandatory measures and recommendations according to the classification of rural property, being considered small those with up to four fiscal modules, medium those that have between four and fifteen fiscal modules, and large ones that exceed fifteen fiscal modules.

Rural real estate owners will have two years to implement the actions.

The Military Emergency Unit (UME) continues deployed in eight fires in the northwest peninsular before the start of a weekend in which the arrival of a dana is expected, which will leave precipitation and a drop in temperatures in these areas, according to the prediction of the spokesman of the State Meteorological Agency (AEMET), José Luis Camacho.


Specifically, there are more than 1,400 military personnel in direct attack deployed; 2,000 in support and relief missions, and 450 means (machinery, drones, etc) in the fires of Yeres, Oencia, Barniedo de la Reina and Anllares del Sil (León); Porto (Zamora); Oímbra-Xinzo de Limia and Seadur-Larouco (Ourense); and Jarilla (Cáceres).
For their part, the Forest Fire Reinforcement Brigades (BRIF) and ground and air troops of the Ministry for Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge (MITECO) are supporting the work of extinguishing 12 fires in seven provinces: León, Zamora, Asturias, Cáceres, Ourense, Lugo and Pontevedra.
Thus, the troops are deployed in Porto (Zamora), Peranzanes (León), Boca de Huérgano (León), Benuza (León), Degaña (Asturias), Somiedo (Asturias), Jarilla (Cáceres), Carballeda de Valdeorras (Ourense), Carballedo (Lugo) and Vilaboa (Pontevedra).
In total, the fire would have devastated up to August 17 295,579.51 hectares in Spain, according to data from the Ministry for Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge (MITECO) based on information provided by the autonomous communities (CCAA) and estimates from the European Commission's Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS) of Copernicus.
The situation is expected to improve this weekend as a dune will leave storms on Sunday afternoon in large areas of the Ebro valley, Pyrenees, Iberian and coastal and pre-coastal areas of the northern half of the Mediterranean, as well as a decrease in the maximum in the western half of the peninsula, according to the forecast of AEMET.
On the other hand, the investigation proceedings of the Civil Guard and the National Police have already left 42 detainees in relation to the different forest fires of this summer in Spain, as well as another 127 people investigated, according to data from the Ministry of Interior updated this August 22.
One of them is a 37-year-old Portuguese man and a resident of Monterroso (Lugo), whom the Civil Guard has charged as investigated as alleged perpetrators of two crimes of forest fire by gross negligence in Folgoso do Courel (Lugo) and Monterroso.
CONCERN FOR THE AREA NEAR LAKE SANABRIA
The provinces of León, Zamora, Palencia, Salamanca and Ávila account for almost all the forest fires affecting Castilla y León in this month of August, where the end of the heat wave has allowed the brigades to gain ground on the fire in this community, where a total of 26 fires are still uncontrolled, of which eight persist in a Potential Severity Index (IGR) 2, six others are at level 1 and 12 in grade 0.
In the case of those classified as more serious, the balance includes the fires of Fasgar, Anllares del Sil, Llamas de la Cabrera, Barniedo, Cardaño de Arriba, Gestoso and Colinas del Campo de Martín Moro, all seven in the province of León, The level 1 level continues in Yeres, Paradiña, Castrocalbón and Canalejas, also in the province of Leon, in addition to those recorded in Molezuelas de la Carballeda (Zamora) and Candelario (Salamanca).
In spite of the improvement in the fight against the fire, a reactivation in the east zone of the fire of Anllares del Sil de León forced the evacuation of the locality of Anllarinos last night.
In the case of the Porto fire, it is still active and flaming near the provincial boundary between Zamora and Leon and with a worrying situation in the Tera Canyon in the area near Lake Sanabria, which still puts in check several localities.
This was explained by the provincial delegate of the Junta in Zamora, Fernando Prada, who has detailed that the situation in the south-east front is better and the Provincial Emergency Coordination Center (Cecopi) has authorized on Friday morning the return home of the inhabitants of Murias and Cerdillo.
Subsequently, the Cecopi has agreed to the relocation of the towns of Vigo, San Martín de Castañeda and San Ciprián affected by the fire that since last August 14, with a Potential Severity Index (IGR 2), originated in Porto and ravages since then the region of Sanabria, according to information provided by the Subdelegation of the Government. The reopening of the ZA-P-2664 road, between Trefacio and Murias, has also been approved.
FIRE STABILIZED IN LAROUCO (OURENSE) AND IMPROVED IN JARILLA (CACERES)
The wave of fires that for two weeks affects Galicia does not give truce and burns already 88,311.5 hectares in fires not extinguished, adding also since the evening of Thursday night three new outbreaks: two in the Pontevedra municipalities of Vilaboa and Oia and one in the Lugo of Carballedo.
On the other hand, when a week of the entry of the Larouco fire in Quiroga (Lugo), technicians begin to consider the fire stabilized, in which there is no flame. This was explained this Friday by the Councillor for the Environment, Luis Manuel Arias, who said that there are no hot spots, but is proceeding to refresh the whole area to prevent the re-activation of outbreaks.
This same fire approached the gates of the municipality of Folgoso do Courel, which already suffered another wave of historic proportions in 2022, but did not get to enter thanks to the work of the brigades for days opening ditches and yesterday with the operatives working with aerial means throughout the day.
The situation is also "quite stabilized" in Folgoso do Courel, in the two fronts that were open (the other by Leon) and where they continue to monitor closely in two crucial points, Outeiro and Ferramulín, to prevent the flames from becoming active again.
Meanwhile, the fire in Jarilla (Cáceres), which has devastated 17,300 hectares, with a perimeter of 170 kilometers, is stabilized and the evacuees will return to their homes this Friday.
The Minister of Presidency, Interior and Social Dialogue of the Board, Abel Bautista, has reported on the measures taken at the meeting of Cecopi on Friday and expressed his satisfaction that the work during this past Thursday and tonight have "yielded results".
CASTILLA Y LEÓN, GALICIA AND EXTREMADURA, WITH MORE BURNED HECTARES
Galicia and Castilla y Leon accumulated 85.3% of the hectares that have burned in Spain between 3 and August 18, 2025, according to data from the European Commission's Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS, for its acronym in English) Copernicus to which Europa Press has had access.
Of the total of 358,034 hectares that have burned between these two dates throughout the country, 43.6% have done so in Galicia (that is, 156,444) and 41.7% have done so in Castilla y León (or what is the same, 149,426). The third place is occupied by Extremadura, which accumulated 44,480 hectares burned, 12.4% of the national total.

The Early Warning System of Forest Fires (Satif) of Santa Cruz alerted of eight active fires reported until Thursday in the Santa Cruz department, whose governor instructed the declaration of departmental emergency.


In addition, the report indicates that to date the accumulated burned area in the current fire season amounts to 95,019 hectares.
The eight fires are registered in the municipalities of Concepción, San Matías, Carmen Rivero Torrez, Roboré, Charagua and San Ignacio de Velasco.
Among the most worrisome are the one that originated in the Caparuch plateau and the one in Concepción. The latter due to the difficulties of access for the response teams, which are now aiming to enter by air.
Active fires
"The Concepción fire is in an area of very complicated access, but we are coordinating with ministries and seeing how to intervene by air" indicated the head of Satif, Leonardo Claure.
The Government of Santa Cruz enabled the Satif Sentinel system, a digital tool for forest fire operations that allows citizens to know the active fires in their region and to access alert broadcasts in the area.
The authorities of the Governor's Office point out that after analyzing satellite images, they came to the conclusion that the fire broke out through a track in the middle of a wooded area, which spreads and no one attends it because it is not currently entered by land.
Meanwhile, Governor Luis Fernando Camacho continues his inspections of the most affected areas in the eastern region. Bringing humanitarian assistance, medical brigades and food for the common pots.
According to the Satif report, currently the most affected municipality is San Ignacio de Velasco with a total of 74,863 hectares, followed by Carmen Rivero (6,543) and San Matías (6,534).

urn:contentItem:6GR1-WSH3-RRSM-6014-00000-00Military firefighters extinguish fire that destroyed 30 ha in Colomi2025-09-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:14ZLexisNexisMilitary firefighters extinguish fire that destroyed 30 ha in Colomi


This Thursday, it was reported that a coordinated operation between the 26th Infantry Regiment 'Juana Azurduy de Padilla', the municipal Risk Management Unit (UGR) and the Government of Cochabamba managed to quell the forest fire that broke out in the municipality of Colomi.


The coordinator of the Ministry of Defense in Cochabamba, Samuel Pereira, informed that 50 military forest firefighters and six instructors were deployed to the community of Chullpani to fight the fire that broke out a few days ago.
"By instruction of the Joint Command of Reaction to Adverse Events, the teams were present in the community of Chullpani since the early hours of yesterday (Wednesday) afternoon to fight the fire," Pereira said this Thursday on the official networks of the Ministry of Defense.
Fire
According to preliminary information, the fire started on Monday night and spread until Wednesday, when personnel were in charge of extinguishing the flames. For the moment, the causes of the fire are unknown, but it is not ruled out that it was intentionally set by someone.
The fire consumed some 30 hectares, reducing to ashes quehuiña trees, grasses, bushes and native species up to two meters high.
The joint action made it possible to control the fire and prevent it from spreading to other areas, said the authorities, who valued the coordinated work between local and national institutions to protect the affected ecosystems.
September is one of the most critical months in the fight against forest fires, because weather conditions, lack of rainfall, dry season and fast winds facilitate the spread of flames.
However, at least for the time being, the effects this year are much less compared to last year, when the Government was forced to activate the national disaster declaration.

urn:contentItem:6GNB-4FX3-RT5B-B0G7-00000-00Government determines participation of rural producers in fighting forest fires2025-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:14ZLexisNexisGovernment determines participation of rural producers in fighting forest fires


The Lula (PT) government has published a series of measures to combat fires on rural properties, which will come into force next Monday (8).
The new measures require rural producers to take part in training for preventive actions against fire, which will be offered by the military fire department, civil defense, or an accredited public or private entity.


The changes are part of the PMIF (National Integrated Fire Management Policy), with the aim of reducing the occurrence of large forest fires and mobilizing human communities that are "resilient to forest fires", according to the decision published by the government.
The publication comes about four months after Comif (the National Committee for Integrated Fire Management) published a resolution in which it stipulated that the state bodies of the National Environment System should, within three months, draw up specific technical criteria for prevention on rural properties.
According to the Ministry of the Environment, as no state or the Federal District managed to complete their regulations within this timeframe, it was up to Comif to establish general guidelines to guide the federal entities.
The new decision, published on Monday, determines that each territory manager must adopt specific plans, such as Forest Fire Prevention and Fighting Plans and Municipal Integrated Fire Management Plans.
The resolution also states that the obligations vary according to the size of the property - small, medium or large - and that it is up to the owners or their legal representatives to draw up and implement the preventive measures.
Among the new obligations for rural producers is to keep their teams trained and equipped to carry out forest fire prevention activities, or to have agreements with institutions, associations, cooperatives and unions that have specialized teams.
Specialized teams can be made up of duly trained and equipped employees, hired or volunteer forest firefighters and military firefighters.
The measures also include rules on the use of fire on rural properties, such as a ban on its use in pastures, agricultural areas, forest management areas with native or exotic species, without prior and formal authorization from the competent environmental agency, among other restrictions.
The use of communication and alert systems to quickly call in neighbors, local private fire brigades, and adherence to fire monitoring, alert and communication systems are also part of the new list of obligations.
The government has been studying these new measures since the beginning of the year. Comif was debating, for example, mechanisms to encourage local or regional fire brigades, and tougher penalties for landowners who fail to comply with their obligations and record consecutive fires on their farms.
In the event of non-compliance with the planned actions, producers and other responsible parties may be subject to prior notification from the competent environmental agency, under penalty of liability.
Family farmers who fall under the law that defines the National Policy for Family Farming and Rural Family Enterprises are exempt from submitting an individual PMIF in collective territories where there is traditional use of fire. In these cases, the PMIF must be submitted by the territory's management body.
Compliance with the measures will be considered a mitigating factor in possible penalties for forest fires.
In 2024, the lack of a gap between the El Niño and La Niña climate phenomena aggravated the drought and brought forward the start of the fire season in Brazil, with a record number of hotspots at the end of the first half of the year.
At the time, the figures put pressure on Lula's administration, which released extraordinary credit, hired firefighters and equipment, set up a crisis committee and lobbied Congress to pass the Integrated Fire Management Law.

urn:contentItem:6GS9-KXJ3-RS2N-51N0-00000-00New deputy forestry minister eyes emission cut, forest sustainability2025-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:14ZLexisNexisNew deputy forestry minister eyes emission cut, forest sustainabilityJakarta

Jakarta, Sept. 18 -- Indonesia's newly inaugurated Deputy Minister of Forestry, Rohmat Marzuki, pledged to give his utmost in helping the country tackle challenges and advance programs linked to the forestry sector.

During a position handover ceremony in Jakarta on Thursday, he noted that the Ministry of Forestry faces a number of pressing issues, including the need to accelerate progress in achieving the FOLU Net Sink 2030 target.

In this context, Marzuki referred to Indonesia's ambition to reach a condition in which the forestry and other land use (FOLU) sector absorbs more emissions than it produces by 2030.

The deputy minister, who replaced Sulaiman Umar Shiddiq in President Prabowo Subianto's Red and White Cabinet, also emphasized the importance of promoting the social forestry initiative, strengthening forest protection, improving forest fire control, and maximizing the potential and value of non-timber forest products.

He expressed confidence that his background and expertise would help in achieving these goals.

"Given my degree in forestry from UGM (Gadjah Mada University), I have long had a deep connection with forestry and the environment. I believe that forests stand as a living space, a source of knowledge, and a pillar of life for communities," Marzuki said.

He then described his cabinet appointment as a valuable opportunity to contribute more to the state and the nation through both the preservation and sustainable use of Indonesia's forest areas.

At the State Palace in Jakarta on Wednesday (September 17), President Prabowo inaugurated 11 leaders of ministries and other state institutions, including Marzuki, who is now tasked with supporting Forestry Minister Raja Juli Antoni in ensuring the sustainability of the country's forests.

He shares responsibilities for protecting forest biodiversity, managing national parks and wildlife sanctuaries, and ensuring fairness in the use of customary forests.

urn:contentItem:6GWB-XWR3-RRTP-T4NG-00000-00Canada's 2025 wildfire season: A national emergency - The Brock Press2025-10-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Canada's 2025 wildfire season: A national emergency - The Brock Press

In September, the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre reported that more than 5,071 fires burned over 8.3 million hectares nationwide. The scope of this destruction has displaced communities, strained provincial firefighting systems and raised urgent questions about how Canada prepares for and responds to climate-driven disasters.

The Prairies were hit particularly hard, with over 33,000 people displaced across Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta, including 17,000 evacuees from Manitoba alone. Together, Saskatchewan and Manitoba accounted for more than half of the land burned nationally. Confirmed fatalities include two deaths from the same small community in Manitoba - though the full toll of injuries and deaths is still being compiled.

Ontario also experienced a surge in fire activity. In the northwest, evacuations were ordered in First Nations communities and one blaze in Kenora District grew to nearly 23,000 hectares before spreading into Manitoba. While southern Ontario avoided catastrophic fires, urban centres were blanketed by smoke. The cities of Toronto and Ottawa as well as the greater Niagara regions faced repeated air-quality alerts - some lasting days at a time - leaving vulnerable populations at risk.

Atlantic Canada, which has historically faced fewer wildfires, recorded what officials called "unprecedented" activity. Newfoundland and Labrador ordered evacuations in Conception Bay North, while New Brunswick closed its forests entirely in August due to extreme danger.

The smoke crisis extended far beyond Canada's borders. As the smoke blanketed the atmosphere and the skies turned orange, air quality alerts were sent across Midwestern and Northern states in the U.S. while simultaneously travelling 7000km across the Atlantic Ocean, covering western European skies numerous times over the summer.

On the international stage, Canada hosted the G7 Kananaskis Wildfire Charter in June. The agreement committed G7 member states to faster data sharing, pooled firefighting resources and climate-fire adaptation strategies. Ottawa launched the Wildfire Resilience Consortium of Canada , which is designed to strengthen wildfire science, forecasting and training. The federal government also provided emergency aid and deployed the Canadian Armed Forces to reinforce provincial firefighting operations.

Many argue that these measures remain inadequate. Canada still lacks a national disaster agency like FEMA in the United States, leaving responses fragmented across provincial jurisdictions. In September, Policy Options critiqued the federal government for failing to implement fire-smart building codes, support Indigenous-led fire stewardship or provide a national smoke health strategy. The lack of agency has left communities without federal assistance to retrofit schools, shelters and public spaces with clean-air infrastructure, despite provinces issuing repeated air-quality alerts and tens of thousands of fire suppression and evacuations just this year alone.

-

From Pacific to Atlantic provinces, flames and smoke disrupted nearly every region of the country, underscoring how climate change is actively reshaping Canada's landscape. The 2025 wildfire season demonstrates that fire is not only a regional challenge, but a nationwide crisis that many experts warn needs a unified federal and provincial combating approach, or Canada risks seeing worse wildfire seasons in the years ahead.

Holbox, QR., The State Coordination of Civil Protection of Quintana Roo informed yesterday that the forest fire located 20 kilometers northwest of this island, which started last August 22 and has affected around 150 hectares, is still active.


The authorities reported 40 percent control and 30 percent liquidation of the conflagration, as a result of the coordinated work of 82 combatants belonging to the National Forestry Commission (Conafor), State Civil Protection Coordination, Municipal Civil Protection, National Commission of Protected Natural Areas, National Defense Secretariat, National Guard, Navy Secretariat and Firefighters.
Three Conafor's RAM vehicles, a Civil Protection ranger, four boats and a Bell 407 helicopter were deployed to fight the fire, in addition to direct firefighting actions, opening of firebreaks, application of backfires, patrolling, surveillance, reconnaissance flights and aerial water discharges.
The general director of the State Civil Protection Coordination, Guillermo Núñez, explained that the personnel have been working in the area since August 25 and the brigades will remain there until the flames are extinguished. At the time of going to press it was not known what caused the conflagration.

The Governorate of Santa Cruz, through the Early Warning System for Forest Fires (Sadif), reported on Tuesday six active fires in the department and an accumulated 95,000 hectares affected.


On Monday, departmental authorities declared red alert in Santa Cruz in application of Law 602 of Risk Management, in order to activate prevention and response mechanisms.
According to Satif data, the six active fires are in San Ignacio de Velasco, San Matías, Carmen Rivero Torrez, Portachuelo, Concepción and Roboré.
As of Monday night there were seven fires, but response personnel quelled the one in Otuquis National Park.
See also: More than 90 forest fires have been extinguished in the country.
Fires
The most complicated situation occurs in the municipality of San Matías, due to the strong winds that fuel the fire and the soil conditions.
"Because of the fires, San Matías is the most complex municipality. It is necessary to mobilize heavy machinery and more personnel with full force to work," said Leonardo Claure, head of Satif.
An internal coordination meeting of the Departmental Emergency Operations Committee (COED) was held. The Governor's Office instructed the mobilization of all the logistic and human resources of the departmental government to attend to the forest fire emergency. It also ordered the delivery of humanitarian aid to provide assistance to the affected areas.
Meanwhile, Governor Luis Fernando Camacho held a meeting with representatives of the FAN and FAO, who expressed their support to the work of the Governor's Office to face the forest fires, based on the analysis of projections being carried out.

The following information was released by Pennsylvania House of Representatives, Republican Caucus:

In response to the devastating wildfires across the nation and the alarming increase in forest fires in Pennsylvania, Rep. Michael Stender (R-Montour/Northumberland), today announced his plan to introduce a comprehensive three-bill package aimed at improving the states ability to prevent, manage and fight wildfires.

This surge in wildfires demands immediate action. If we want to protect our communities, our first responders, and our natural resources, we must invest in wildfire prevention and response efforts, said Stender. The bills I will introduce are designed to enhance our states ability to combat wildfires, strengthen our forest fire response infrastructure and ensure the safety of all Pennsylvanians.

The three bills include:

Elevating the Chief Forest Fire Warden: This bill would elevate the chief forest fire warden to the level of deputy secretary within the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources (DCNR), ensuring greater authority and support for wildfire prevention and response efforts.

Reimbursements for Local Forest Fire Wardens: This bill would require DCNR to reimburse local forest fire wardens for training, fire investigations, prescribed burns, and public outreach, supporting the vital work of these volunteer first responders.

Annual Forest Fire Reports: This bill would mandate an annual report from the chief forest fire warden to the General Assembly, providing updates on wildfire prevention efforts and the states progress in combating forest fires.

We must act now to ensure Pennsylvania is prepared for the growing threat of wildfires and our communities are safer in the years to come, said Stender.

urn:contentItem:6GPP-BCN3-RT3X-803K-00000-00Houston council advances work on climate action and adaptation plan2025-09-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Houston council advances work on climate action and adaptation planMarisca Bakker

The District of Houston is continuing its work to create a climate action and adaptation plan.

At the Sept. 2 regular meeting of council, Pinna Sustainability introduced the Houston Climate Action and Adaptation Plan.

The meeting discussed the Climate Action and Adaptation Plan for Houston, focusing on reducing greenhouse gas emissions and building resilience.

The District retained Pinna Sustainability in May 2025 to lead the development of the plan for the District of Houston. They started working on it in June 2025 and have now completed phases one and two.

The plan, developed in four phases, aims to align with existing policies and set new goals.

Houston’s GHG emissions increased by 29 per cent from 2007 to 2022, with transportation and buildings being major contributors.

Key climate hazards identified include wildfire, smoke, drought, and extreme heat. The plan includes strategies for active transportation, electric vehicles, and emergency response for vulnerable populations.

“The next steps currently for phase 3 and 4 are to start to develop emission reduction targets as outlined with the BC government as well as engage with various groups to start to develop goals and actionable lists of project which can support the mitigation and adaptation plans through the climate action plan,” said the District’s project manager Scott Sanders.

“We hope to have a reasonable list of short-, medium-and long-term project opportunities identified around the District which will support these efforts in climate action. These can be forest fire prevention, flood mitigation, GHG reduction through district-owned properties, as examples.”

The next steps also involve further public engagement and finalizing the plan by January 2026.

urn:contentItem:6GN4-5DF3-S4Y1-9534-00000-008 of the 10 largest fires of the century are from 20252025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:14ZLexisNexis8 of the 10 largest fires of the century are from 2025


They haven't finished putting them all out yet, and 2025 is already known to be one of the worst years in history since fire records have been kept, with nearly 400,000 hectares burned. In fact, 8 of the 10 major fires of the century have occurred this year. This year's season has only been surpassed in 1985, 1978, 1994 and 1989. The uniqueness of 2025 is that the average number of burned hectares of large wildfires (from now on GIF) has been exceeded. Thus, the GIF average has risen to 6,100 hectares, whereas up to now it had been 1,500 ha/GIF.


In other words, each large forest fire is burning four times more area than usual. For Greenpeace, these figures are a clear sign of how climate change continues to accelerate and aggravate extreme weather events such as fires, heat waves and floods. For this reason, the NGO has relied on the renowned social and environmental photographer Pedro Armestre, to document from the air the magnitude of the destruction, even reaching areas not photographed so far in the regions of Sanabria (Zamora), El Bierzo (León), or in Orense: in Larouco (the largest in the history of Galicia), Xinzo de Limia and Chadrexa de Queixa-Vilariño de Conso.
While the economic consequences of the forest fires are yet to be gauged, the arson crisis leaves burned houses, blackened villages, destroyed farms and livestock farms, affected businesses and forests and scrublands reduced to ashes, many of them part of valuable protected natural areas. To date, 8 people have died, at least 50 have been injured and more than 30,000 people have been displaced. A social, economic and environmental impact very difficult to capture with a camera.
"From the air, what you see is not just scorched earth: it is homes lost, landscapes turned to ash and a future that is extinguished. It's a country on fire and an emergency that we can no longer ignore: if we don't invest in prevention and forest management, every summer will be worse than the last," Armestre explained.
"2025 unfortunately is a historic year, in which each fire has been much more destructive than the previous ones. It is urgent to manage the forest masses that are the stage where the fire takes place. And in parallel, work must be done on the State Pact to define an ambitious national roadmap with binding commitments, stable funding, citizen participation, a system of accountability and a special focus on those in vulnerable situations," added Mónica Parrilla de Diego, head of the Greenpeace forest fire campaign.
Spain, with 27.9 million hectares of forest land occupying 55.2% of the national territory, is the country with the second largest forest area in the EU, behind Sweden. However, the abandonment of the rural environment and the traditional use of agriculture and forestry have increased the area of young vegetation, with an excess of density aggravated by the absence of herbivores. While the criminal use of fire persists, "urbanization" and recreational use of the forest have resulted in a greater risk of ignition and propagation.
Likewise, the summer of 2025 also accumulated records that explain the virulence of the fires and the difficulties in extinguishing them. A 16-day heat wave has aggravated the fires that have ravaged the peninsula and has broken historical records in the country, ranking as the most intense since official data has been available. Spain has become one of the territories most affected by the climatic emergency, which aggravates several impacts: large forest fires, desertification, torrential rains, floods and loss of water resources.

Madrid (España): Complejo de la Moncloa has issued the following news release:

The President of the Government of Spain has insisted on the need to reach a State Pact to deal with the climate emergency, 'leaving aside partisan fighting'. 'We will strive to ensure that this happens and that we can reach this great agreement between parties, institutions and society as a whole.'

On behalf of the Executive and the country as a whole, Pedro Sánchez thanked the 'commendable work, professionalism, commitment to the territory and the immense effort' of the Forest Fire Reinforcement Brigades (BRIF) in tackling the fires suffered by our country. 'The recognition of the firefighters of the Ministry of Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge and also the applause of Spanish society as a whole for their work throughout these difficult weeks,' in which they have had to 'work and battle side by side with many other troops from all over Spain,' he said.

Speaking to the media after his visit to the base of the Forest Fire Reinforcement Brigade in Tabuyo del Monte (León), the head of the Executive stressed that the deployment of the BRIF has included the mobilisation of the 11 brigades we have throughout the territory, with a total of more than 600 personnel and more than 200 resources. To this must be added the 'unprecedented mobilisation of the Government of Spain, the State law enforcement forces and agencies, the Civil Guard, the National Police, the Military Emergency Unit and volunteers.' 'All the troops of the General State Administration have been made available to work in coordination with the autonomous communities affected by these fires,' he recalled.

Sánchez stressed that BRIF workers are public servants who 'put their lives at risk' and should have 'salary dignity' and job 'stability', while at the same time it is necessary to 'increase the resources and means they have to be able to do their work better and with greater guarantees of safety'. This is the guide for the political action of both the Ministry of Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge and the public company Tragsa itself, said the president, who recalled that in 2024 'a very important step was taken with the approval of the basic framework for brigades, forest firefighters and environmental agents', which improves their conditions. 'It is now up to the regional governments to do the same for the personnel that are under their jurisdiction and that form part of their administrations,' he said.

State Pact to tackle the climate emergency

During his speech, the president of the Government of Spain insisted on the 'need for all administrations, and not just the administrations, to work hand in hand on a State Pact to tackle the climate emergency,' which transcends legislatures. In this sense, he recalled that in the last Council of Ministers the Government had approved 'a participatory, open, absolutely democratic roadmap', so that experts can contribute their knowledge and proposals, and that by the end of the year we can have a State pact that will allow us to guide our actions in a systematic and systemic way over the coming months and years.'

In his opinion, 'it is worth making this effort and putting aside everything related to the legitimate and democratic party struggle' to reach this agreement on the climate emergency, as we did in the past with the State Pact against terrorism, or against sex-based violence, because 'in the end what we are talking about is the security of our people.'

Sánchez stressed that the Government's will to reach this State Pact is 'absolute'. 'We are going to strive, as I will personally, to ensure that this happens and that we can reach this great agreement, this great State Pact between parties and institutions, but also the whole of Spanish society, because we need everyone.' 'We need the primary sector, environmental NGOs, but also urban and rural areas working together against this climate emergency,' he concluded.
